repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Urban Transport Reform and
            Capacity Building Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is marginally
            satisfactory, with project achievements likely to be
            sustained. Both the World Bank and Borrower performances are
            rated as satisfactory. The lessons learned include the
            following: Establishing a partnership between the
            Government, municipalities, and the private sector in order
            to develop appropriate solutions to public transport issues
            in a big metropolitan area is an excellent approach.
            However, considerable efforts are required to initiate and
            nurture such an innovative process. Second, it is important
            to promise only what can be effectively delivered;
            performance indicators should have been revised following
            the scaling down of the project. Third, it is not enough to
            expect stakeholders to make voluntary contributions to a
            development fund, even if they are part of the
            decision-making process. Fourth, privatization of a public
            bus company is extremely difficult; liquedation is not an
            option because of pressures from powerful groups and the
            problems resulting from a vastly increased urban congestion.
            Fifth, while it makes senses to focus on establishing an
            adequate institutional framework before initiating a large
            investment program, there is a risk that stakeholders may be
            demobilized by delaying much-needed investment.

694179.trustfund:
TF036392-SENEGAL - URBAN TRANSPORT
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF034500-SENEGAL - URBAN TRANSPORT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Urban Transport Reform and
            Capacity Building (Technical Assistance) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Urban
            Transport Reform and Capacity Building (Technical
            Assistance) Project is to assist in providing more
            affordable, reliable, and safer public transport services in
            the metropolitan area of Dakar. This project includes two
            main components: (1) Institutional development through
            consultant's services and short-term technical
            assistance, training and an awareness campaign to (a)
            establish and manage a coordinating body, which will gather
            the main actors of the sector; (b) privatize the Senegalese
            bus company, including assisting the development of a
            leasing scheme for urban transport operators, and revising
            the regulatory framework for providing urban transport
            services; (c) establish a sustainable financing mechanism
            for the sector through an urban transport development fund;
            and (d) implement a traffic management scheme and a road
            safety action plan with users participation; and (2) Minor
            civil works such as rehabilitating bus stops, bus lane
            arrangements, fitting encroachments, and intermodal slots.
